titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Finding aid prepared by Brian Carpenter

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2013-09-13T21:12-0400

did.abstract: Linguistic field recordings of Nlaka'pamuctsin, also known as the Thompson, Ntlakyapamuk, or Nlaka'pamux language. Primary consists of grammatical and lexical elicitations sessions. Also includes various brief narratives about wood gathering, picking berries, hunting, fishing, digging for roots, basket making, food preparation, and childhood memories. Recorded by Paul Kroeber in Lower Nicola and Merritt, British Columbia, from October 1990 to March 1992 with consultants Mabel Joe and Kathy York.
did.physdesc: 45 sound cassettes (39 hr., 57 min.) : analog, 1 7/8 ips, stereo.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Donated by Paul D. Kroeber in 1992 (Acc. 1992-652r). This material was recorded with the assistance of a Phillips Fund grant.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Original tapes numbered TH-K 9 to TH-K 53 by collector.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Extensive field notes from these recordings, prior recording sessions, and related linguistic fieldwork are available in the Phillips Fund Collection (Mss.497.3.Am4).

originalsloc.head: Existence and Location of Originals note
originalsloc.p: This file is a compressed, digitized version of the original. The APS Library maintains the original format (Audiocassette) as well as an uncompressed digitized version of this recording.

did.unittitle: Ntlakyapamuk (Thompson-Salish) grammatical elicitation and lexical data

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes brief discussion at 27:00 of an earlier group of Ntlakyapamuk Indians who died out.

did.unittitle: Three Ntlakyapamuk narratives followed by translations

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Three short narratives given in Ntlakyapamuk through 6:11, followed by free translations into English.
